Energy Strategy and Low-carbon Development Research Center Sichuan Energy Internet Research Institute, Tsinghua University Chengdu 610200 China To achieve the global net-zero carbon emissions target, enhanced studies on how to effectively convert and utilize CO2 have been conducted. Herein, the research progress and development trend of CO2 conversion to chemicals, including CO2 hydrogenation to hydrocarbons, CO2 as an oxidant to syngas, and CO2 cycloaddition to carbonate were discussed in this review. The principles, advantages, disadvantages, and prospects of thermal catalysis, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, enzyme catalysis, and plasma catalysis for CO2 conversion were summarized. Among them, the different methods of the active component, carrier, catalyst electronic effect, synergistic effect and size effect used to develop specific catalysts for different CO2 conversions were introduced emphatically. Moreover, the developmental stage of CO2 catalytic conversion technology and important industrial demonstration projects in China were summarized, with special emphasis on the relationship between hydrogen/electricity supply and the carbon emission reduction effect of CO2 catalytic conversion. The reaction network, catalytic system and demonstration project of CO2 catalytic conversion were comprehensively compared and discussed to more clearly play the beneficial role of CO2 catalytic conversion in carbon reduction work. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation CO2 electroreduction CO2 photoreduction CO2 cycloaddition Catalytic conversion Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Climate change caused by carbon dioxide emissions is a major and urgent global challenge facing mankind. To achieve net-zero emissions during the use of fossil fuels, the fossil fuels industry of carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) has attracted more attention [1,2]. In recent years, China has attached great importance to the development of CCUS and the maturity of relevant technologies has improved rapidly, followed by a series of demonstration projects being launched [3]. In “The 14th Five-Year Plan and the Outline of the Long-range Goals for 2035″ of China, CCUS has been regarded as a major demonstration project. In the future, CCUS technology will play a more significant role in China's process of achieving carbon neutrality, ensuring national energy security, promoting the comprehensive green transformation of economic and social development, and facilitating the construction of ecological civilization. According to a related research report from Tsinghua University, In a carbon-neutral scenario, captured CO2 by CCUS could reach about 1.6 billion tons in 2060 [4]. As an important C1 resource, the catalytic conversion of CO2 into high value-added chemical products can not only alleviate greenhouse gas emissions, but also realize effective exploitation of resources. The research of CO2 catalytic conversion technology has been developed rapidly in China, including starch [5], glucose and aliphatic acid [6], olefin [7], polylactic acid (PLA) [8], and formic acid based materials synthesis [9] and so on. There are four pathways for the conversion of CO2 [10–13]: (1) Reduced by hydrogen to produce methanol and other chemicals; (2) obtaining synthesis gas by dry reforming of methane (DRM) and reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reactions, and coupled with downstream chemical synthesis technology to implement indirect conversion and utilization of CO2; reacting with epoxides to produce cyclocarbonate or polycarbonate chemicals; (3) producing urea, salicylic acid and other chemical production processes. Among them, only urea, ethyl carbonate, salicylic acid, aliphatic polycarbonate, sodium carbonate and other carbonate products have been produced on an industrial scale [14]. Although CO2 is a low-cost, nontoxic, abundant and readily available renewable carbon resource, it has high thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness. The bond energy of C=O is up to 750 kJ/mol, which is much higher than that of the C–C bond (336 kJ/mol), C–O bond (327 kJ/mol), and C–H bond (411 kJ/mol) [15]. Consequently, a high energy input is required to convert them into higher value-added chemicals. To realize the catalytic conversion of CO2, the addition of high energy reducing agents (e. g. H2) or extra energy (e. g. electrical or light energy) is the requisite for breaking the C=O bond. Moreover, various catalysts also can be used to reduce the activation energy and temperature of CO2 reduction reaction to convert the CO2 efficiently. The catalyst research mainly focuses on the preparation of catalyst, auxiliary agent, carrier and catalyst carrier effect [16]. Electrocatalysis and photocatalysis are currently receiving extensive attention from researchers, but considering industrial amplification, thermal catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 is still the most promising synthesis route for high value-added chemicals and liquid fuels [17]. The biggest barrier for this pathway is where H2 comes from, which can be obtained by electricity generation from renewable energy sources (e. g. wind, biomass or solar) and water electrolysis in current [18]. The technological innovation of CO2 catalytic conversion is conducive to the further upgrading of chemical industry. With the maturity of technology and the support of policies, chemicals from the CO2 catalytic conversion process will gain wider industrial applications [19]. However, no review has been documented to suggest the selection of conversion pathways and catalysts for the industrial application of CO2 catalytic conversion, nor has it disclosed the latest progress of the demonstration project of CO2 catalytic conversion to chemicals in China and the impact of supporting units. This review includes the study of CO2 chemical reaction networks, catalytic systems and catalysts and the progress of CO2 catalytic conversion demonstration projects in China. Starting from the CO2 conversion pathway, hydrogenation of CO2 to produce the high value-added chemical products, reforming (or gasification) of CO2 into syngas and the reaction principle of CO2 conversion into fine chemical products were introduced. Then, the basic principle and characteristics of catalytic conversion of CO2 under different catalytic systems (including thermal catalysis, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, enzyme catalysis and low temperature plasma catalysis) were discussed. Furthermore, the effects of active components, carriers, electronic effects, synergistic effects and size effects on the catalytic conversion of CO2 were explored. Finally, the developmental stages of different CO2 catalytic conversion technologies and important industrial demonstration projects in China were summarized, and the effects of hydrogen and electricity supply on the low-carbon development of CO2 catalytic conversion technologies were examined. 2 CO2 chemical reaction network The design of reaction network and the selection of the best reaction path are the first steps for the conversion of CO2 into high value-added chemicals. Fig. 1 shows the main reaction network of the catalytic conversion of CO2, which mainly includes four pathways: (1) hydrogenation to convert hydrocarbons; (2) synthesis gas and gaseous hydrocarbon with CO2 as oxidant; (3) preparation of high polymer by CO2 ring addition; (4) other conversion and utilization pathways represented by urea production. Among them, the first three CO2 catalytic conversion technologies are mostly in the industrial test or laboratory research stage. The scale application of urea and salicylic acid from CO2 is relatively common, so this paper will not elaborate. 2.1 CO2 hydrogenation High value-added chemicals produced by CO2 hydrogenation mainly include methanol, formic acid, dimethyl ether, olefin, high carbon alcohol, liquid fuel, etc., and H2 is used as a raw material in the production process of these high value-added chemicals. The hydrogenation of CO2 mainly focuses on the methanol intermediate path and CO intermediate path, as depicted in Fig. 2 [16]. The CO intermediate path is the conversion of CO2 to CO through the RWGS reaction and then produces hydrocarbon compounds by Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS). The methanol intermediate path is through a methanol synthesis reaction, followed by methanol coupling dehydration to produce hydrocarbon chemicals. The catalyst used in the first step is similar to the FTS catalyst [20]. In the second step, the selection of catalytic materials mainly focuses on the combination of catalyst for methanol production and molecular sieve material for methanol dehydration polymerization [21]. The reaction equations for RWGS and methanol synthesis are shown in Eq. (1) and Eq. (2), respectively. For the conversion of CO2 to CO by the reverse water gas conversion reaction, the adsorption of CO (ads) on the catalyst surface is required to be weak to avoid further hydrogenation. Therewith, the particle size of metal catalyst can be reduced or the dispersion of metal catalyst can be promoted by adding structural auxiliaries to change the adsorption configuration of CO (ads) on the catalyst surface and then reduce the adsorption strength of CO (ads) to enhance CO (ads) rapid removal and CO generation [22,23]. For the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the main reaction is exothermic and less chaotic and the side reaction as reverse water gas reaction is an endothermic process with constant chaos, so high pressure and low temperature are thermodynamically conducive to the conversion of CO2 to methanol [17]. Due to the limitation of kinetics, the reaction temperature above 200 °C is usually used, but an extremely high temperature is not conducive to the improvement of methanol selectivity [24]. (1) C O 2 ( g ) + H 2 ( g ) → CO ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) Δ H 298 K = 41.1 kJ / mol (2) C O 2 ( g ) + 3 H 2 ( g ) → C H 3 OH ( l ) + H 2 O ( g ) Δ H 298 K = − 87 kJ / mol Common catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation include metal oxides, metal carbides, metal sulfides and transition metal-supported catalysts [25–30]. Metal oxide catalysts usually have good selectivity for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol [25]. However, the activation ability of H2 is poor, the conversion rate of CO2 is low (generally no more than 10%), and the conversion temperature and pressure are high, which requires equipment more stringent. Metal carbide and sulfide catalysts show good hydrogenation activity and selectivity of CO2 [26,27]. However, the preparation condition of metal carbide catalyst is harsh, the phase transformation is prone to occurring under the reaction condition, and the cyclic stability of catalyst is poor. Sulfur may be precipitated during the preparation and reaction of metal sulfide catalysts. Considering the environmental problems, it is profitless for industrial applications. Transition metals (Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, Ni, Cu, Co, etc.) have excellent H2 activation ability [28]. Therefore, transition metal hydrogenation catalysts supported by metal oxides have been widely studied. The oxide carrier can not only disperse the active metal and improve its specific surface area, but also adjust the adsorption and activation state of substrates and intermediates due to the reducibility and acid-base sites on the carrier surface [29]. In addition, the strong interactions between the metal and the carrier, such as charge transfer or the formation of interfacial sites, can regulate the hydrogenation activity of CO2 on the catalyst and the selectivity of the products CO, CH4, HCOOH and CH3OH [30]. The strong interaction between metal and carrier, catalytic active center, CO2 adsorption behavior, formation of intermediates and catalytic reaction mechanism are hotspots and difficulties in the study of CO2 reduction at present. 2.2 CO2 as oxidant Syngas is the cornerstone of the chemical synthesis industry and has enormous market demand. It can combine some of the already industrialized carbon-chemical technology to produce high-value chemicals and liquid fuels according to the market demand. DRM and CO2 gasification can be used to produce syngas. It can not only achieve the purpose of efficient use of natural gas and coke but also effectively reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Albeit DRM reaction has many advantages in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, its reaction characteristics still have some difficulties [31]. For instance, DRM reaction has a complex reaction system. In addition to the main reaction (Eq. (3)), it is usually accompanied by RWGS (Eq. (1)), CH4 decomposition (Eq. (4)) and CO disproportionation (Eq. (5)) and other side reactions. Obviously, the DRM reaction is a strongly endothermic reaction, which requires high temperature to promote the reaction. Due to the presence of the side reaction RWGS, more CO is produced during the reaction, so the quantity ratio of hydrogen to carbon substances in the total reaction products is less than 1 [32]. In the whole reaction system, the carbon accumulation mainly comes from the CH4 decomposition reaction and CO disproportionation reaction [33]. Since the DRM reaction takes place in the thermodynamic carbon deposition zone, it is unrealizable to improve the carbon deposition of the DRM reaction by changing the thermodynamic conditions of the reaction. The only way to improve the main reaction rate and reduce the occurrence of side reactions is to design catalysts [34]. (3) C O 2 ( g ) + C H 4 ( g ) → 2 CO ( g ) + 2 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K = 247 kJ / mol (4) C H 4 ( g ) → C ( s ) + 2 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K = 74.6 kJ / mol (5) 2 CO ( g ) → C ( s ) + C O 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K = − 172.4 kJ / mol In DRM reaction at high temperatures, the deactivation of catalyst is mainly caused by carbon accumulation and sintering of active components. Carbon deposition is a process in which the carbon species produced by the cleavage of CH4 on the catalyst surface are overlaid at the active site, reducing the contact between the reactant and the active metal [35]. In severe cases, the carbon covered on the catalyst surface further forms inert carbon, or even completely covers the active site, thus deactivating the catalyst. Sintering is the migration and agglomeration of the active metal at high temperatures, which reduces the number of active sites and leads to a decrease in activity, resulting in catalyst deactivation [36]. In the process of reaction, the active metal is oxidized and a solid phase reaction occurs with the support or auxiliary agent, and the collapse of the carrier pore structure at high temperature will also cause the catalyst deactivation [37]. Ni can be combined with other catalysts to effectively alter the surface properties of catalysts to obtain better catalytic performance, so it is often used to inhibit carbon deposition and sintering in the DRM process [38]. Using CO2 as a gasification agent has the advantages of expediting the gasification reaction rate, improving the gasification efficiency and reducing the gasification temperature [39]. In the gasification process of coke and CO2, it is necessary to enhance the reactivity of coke to enhance the conversion rate. The reactivity of coke is affected by the pyrolysis conditions, the structural properties of coke and the ash composition of coke. The results show that a lower pyrolysis temperature and higher heating rate can improve the reactivity of coke [40]. On the contrary, the small pore volume (and mainly micropores) and more aromatic structure of coke will reduce the reactivity of coke gasification [41]. In addition, alkali metal carbonates or hydroxides and ferric salts have been found to effectively promote the CO2 gasification of various biomass [42]. 2.3 CO2 cycloaddition Synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 is an environmentally friendly method that is more in line with the carbon balance strategy. Cyclic carbonate has been widely used in textile, electrochemical, organic synthesis and other fields, and is an important compound [43]. Under the action of a catalyst, the cyclic addition reaction of CO2 and epoxide to prepare cyclic carbonate can occur under mild conditions, and the driving force of the reaction mainly comes from the release of ternary ring tension of epoxide. In addition, the reaction has 100% atomic economy, and the resulting cyclic carbonate is a long-term stable compound that meets the requirements of carbon storage better than other chemicals. Moreover, cyclic carbonate has broad application prospects, which can be used as an organic synthesis intermediate, polar aprotic solvent, lithium battery electrolyte and polymer synthesis monomer [44]. As shown in Fig. 3 , the reaction steps of CO2 cycloaddition reaction are divided into three steps [45]: First, the nucleophile attacks the epoxide and causes it to ring open and form alkyl oxygen and then, alkylated oxygen is inserted into CO2 to form a carbonate anion; finally, annular carbonates are generated by nucleophilic addition cyclization reaction inside the carbonate anion. Both experimental studies and theoretical calculations confirm that the cycle-opening of epoxides is the key step to determining the cycle-addition reaction rate of CO2 [46]. There are usually two ways to promote the activation and ring-opening of epoxides. One way is to use metal ions as Lewis acids to activate epoxides through metal-O coordination bonds [47]. The other way is to use -OH, -COOH, -NH- and other hydrogen bond donors reacting with the oxygen atoms of epoxides are bonded by hydrogen, and then the epoxides are polarized and the ring is easily opened by a subsequent nucleophile attack [48]. In addition, to improve the reaction rate, the specific surface area of the carrier can be increased to improve the adsorption capacity of CO2. By designing activation sites that can interact with a hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom of CO2, CO2 can be adsorbed, enriched and activated on the catalyst surface to promote the interaction with epoxides. To obtain a satisfactory yield in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, it is necessary to add nucleophiles (cocatalysts) to promote the reaction. In most cases, the nucleophile is generally selected as a cocatalyst such as a halogen quaternary ammonium salt Bu4NBr [49]. Catalysts used for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 include metal halides, metal oxides, ionic liquids, organic bases, metal complexes, metal organic frame materials (MOFs) and porous organic polymers (POPs) and so on [50]. However, epoxide has high preparation cost, high toxicity, difficult storage and low production efficiency. Homogeneous metal complexes, such as Al, Co, Mn, Zn, Cr and Mg, are the preferred catalysts for the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates at atmospheric pressures and ambient temperatures. Nevertheless, most of these metal catalysts have some drawbacks, such as poor selectivity, low sensitivity to hydrolysis or oxidation, high toxicity, difficult recycling and difficult product separation [51]. In this regard, MOFs materials with uniform pores in the framework show great potential as multiphase catalysts for CO2-epoxide conversion [52]. In addition, to improve the catalytic efficiency, some catalysts need to use cocatalysts, such as n-tetrabutylammonium bromide and similar ammonium salts, but the separation of ammonium salts has become a new problem. 3 Catalytic conversion of CO2 3.1 Catalytic system The catalyst can accomplish CO2 conversion through the adsorption and activation of CO2 molecules on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the adsorption sites of CO2 molecules and the formation and change process of reaction intermediates in different catalytic systems are essential to explore [16,53]. A series of compounds such as CO, CH4, CH3OH, HCOOH and cyclocarbonate can be synthesized by CO2 in the system of thermal catalysis, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, enzyme catalysis and plasma catalysis. 3.1.1 Thermo-catalytic conversion Thermal catalysis is widely used, and can obtain a variety of target products and high product yield with comparative ease, mainly including hydrogenation conversion, dry reforming of methane, etc. Fig. 4 illustrates the influence of reaction temperature on CO2 conversion and product selectivity at the equilibrium of methanol synthesis, RWGS and DRM under their respective conventional reaction conditions. When the reaction temperature is between 100 and 280 °C, the conversion of CO2 and the selectivity of the product in methanol synthesis gradually decrease. However, when the reaction temperature is higher than 280 °C, the enhancement of the side reaction leads to the gradual increase of CO2 conversion in methanol synthesis. High temperature is not only beneficial to increase CO2 conversion and product selectivity in RWGS reaction. But also conducive to improving the conversion of CO2 in the DRM reaction, nonetheless the carbon deposition in the DRM reaction has an inflection point when the reaction temperature increases. Many possible products exist for the thermal catalytic conversion of CO2, among which methanol is a vital industrial raw material and an alternative fuel. Taking methanol synthesis as an example, the catalysts for CO2-catalyzed methanol production can be roughly divided into methanol synthesis catalysts and FTS catalysts. Methanol synthesis catalyst is mainly prepared by modifying Zn/Cr oxides or Cu with alkali metals [54]. FTS catalyst adopts alkali metal to promote Cu-Co-M-A catalyst system (M=Cr, Fe, Mn, etc., and A= alkali metal), and the reaction temperature and pressure are low [55,56]. Among all metals, Cu has excellent catalytic performance in conducting the methanol synthesis reaction under mild conditions. The most widely used catalyst for industrial methanol synthesis is Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, in which Cu is the active component, ZnO can promote the dispersion of active component, and Al2O3 mainly acts as the skeleton and also can increase the surface area of Cu [57]. Yet due to the inhibition of product water and the side reaction - RWGS and other factors, the activity and selectivity of Cu/ZnO/ Al2O3 are low, it is necessary to develop new catalysts with higher activity and selectivity [58]. 3.1.2 Electrocatalytic conversion The electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide is regarded as a CO2 conversion technology with great development prospects and in line with the concept of sustainable development. Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is a process of reducing CO2 to chemicals and fuels (such as CO, formic acid, methane, ethylene, ethanol, propanol, etc.) by electrochemical means [59]. An electrocatalytic reduction system is commonly composed of an electrode, ion exchange membrane and electrolyte. CO2 reduction reaction occurs at the working electrode (cathode) and the oxygen evolution reaction occurs at the opposite electrode (anode). The ion exchange membrane is used to separate the anode and the cathode chamber to prevent the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 products from being oxidized by the oxygen produced by the anode. According to the type of electrolyte, it can be divided into an aqueous solution system, an organic electrolytic liquid system and an ionic liquid system [60]. Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is a complex process, usually involving 2–18 different electron transfer reactions, depending on the number of electron transfers, the resulting products generally consist of CO, methanol, formaldehyde, methane, formic acid, ethylene, ethanol, acetic acid, propanol, etc. Table 1 shows the corresponding reaction equations and reduction potentials of different reduction products. Taking the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 for methanol production as an example, CO adsorbed state is a crucial intermediate for methanol generation. The specific pathway is demonstrated in Fig. 5 [61]. Firstly, ⋅COOH was obtained by the hydrogenation of CO2 at the cathode, and then ⋅CO and H2O of the adsorption state were obtained by further hydrogenation. After obtaining ⋅CO with adsorption state, ⋅CHO was obtained by hydrogenation first and then ⋅CH2O (or desorption to formaldehyde) was obtained by hydrogenation. The adsorption methoxy (⋅OCH3) was obtained by three times hydrogenation. The final step was hydrogenation, reduction and desorption to methanol. Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is a comparatively complex process. Currently, catalysts for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 are still a challenge. Catalysts with sufficient catalytic activity and stability have not been developed yet, and there is still a large gap from large-scale industrialization. Catalytic materials for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 can be divided into metal materials and non-metal materials, among which metal catalysts are the most common, especially transition metal catalysts [62]. 3.1.3 Photocatalytic conversion Photocatalysis is a green technology that can directly convert solar energy into chemical energy, which was developed by Lehn et al. in 1982 [63], who took the lead in using this technology to convert CO2, it becomes a new way of CO2 conversion. In the photocatalytic reaction, the selection of photocatalyst is of great consequence. At present, the main materials of photocatalysts are semiconductor materials, metal complexes, perovskite materials and MOFs [64,65]. According to the different types of photocatalysts, the mechanism of CO2 reduction is also different. For metallic compounds, there are mainly two types of photocatalysts including semiconducting and metal complexes. Thus, there are two basic principles for reducing CO2, as depicted in Fig. 6 . For semiconductor photocatalyst, when the catalyst is illuminated by light with an energy equal to or greater than the band gap width, the valence band (VB) electrons will be excited to the conduction band (CB), and then electrons migrate to the surface of the catalyst and the adsorbed CO2 reacts, leaving positively charged holes in the VB [15]. For oxidation to occur, the VB potential must be more positive than the required oxidation potential, and for reduction to occur, the CB potential must be more negative than the required reduction potential. Ideally, photogenerated electrons migrate to the surface of the catalyst and then react with CO2 adsorbed on the surface [15]. The mechanism of photocatalytic reduction of CO2 by metal complexes is different from that of semiconductor materials. In most cases, the transformation takes place through the reduction-quenching pathway, which involves three main stages: first, photocatalysts (PC) generate the corresponding excited states (PC*) through metal-to-ligand-charge-transfer (MLCT) between metals and ligands after light irradiation and then, the excited catalyst (PC*) obtains electrons from the reducing agent to form the reduced complex (PC−1); finally, the reduced complex is reoxidized to PC, while CO2 is reduced to CO, CH4, etc. [66]. In addition, photocatalytic CO2 reduction can be directly coupled with photocatalytic water splitting to achieve sustainable green fuel production [67]. Combining the two kinds of photocatalytic reaction mechanisms, the improvement of photocatalytic efficiency of photocatalysts is mainly required to improve the range of light absorption and catalytic reaction efficiency. At present, the conversion rate of CO2 by photocatalytic reduction is low, and the yield is mostly μmol/(g·h) level. Moreover, the use of sacrificial agents or reducing agents increases the cost and reduces environmental friendliness, so the research and design of photocatalysts is still a difficult task. Conventional photocatalysts, such as TiO2, have low energy efficiency due to the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes [68]. Cui et al. [69] prepared a type of 3-D porous thermoplastic polyurethane/ titania/ polydopamine composite foam to improve the shortcomings of TiO2 nanoparticles that are easy to be aggregated and are too small to recycle. Jiang et al. [70] synthesize composite photocatalysts of flower-like bismuth tungstate (Bi2WO6) and carbon nanospheres (CSs) (named CSs-Bi2WO6). Due to its high visible light utilization and reasonable band gap (2.53 eV), CSs-Bi2WO6 showed good photocatalytic properties. Recently, inorganic metal halide perovskites (MHPs) have displayed outstanding advantages such as high photon-to-electron conversion efficiency and photoluminescence quantum yield, which present great potential in optoelectronics [71]. 3.1.4 Enzymatic catalytic conversion Enzyme-catalyzed conversion is to reduce CO2 by simulating the process of photosynthesis, which usually requires redox enzymes as catalysts and artificial microorganisms to complete the process. Redox biocatalysts involve dehydrogenases such as aldehydes, formic acid, lactic acid and alcohol dehydrogenase. Fig. 7 shows the process of CO2 reduction by biological photosynthesis [72]. The main components are photoredox and biocatalytic systems. Photoredox unit includes an electron donor, photosensitizer, electron carrier and photocatalyst. Biocatalytic systems usually use natural coenzymes- nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and its reduction form (NADH). In the established enzyme system, the essence of CO2 conversion is to activate the substrate molecules with enzymes to reduce the activation energy required for the reaction to accelerate the reaction rate and moderate the reaction conditions. Lyase and redox reductase are paramount enzymes in the synthesis of CO, formic acid, methane and other fuels or useful compounds. In the process of CO2 conversion, lyases (such as carbonic anhydrase) can promote the breaking of chemical bonds. The main role of redox enzymes (formate dehydrogenase, CO2 reductase, nitrogenase, etc.) is to promote electron transport, and the coenzymes NADPH/NADP+ or NADH/NAD+ are the key cofactors. CO2 can be converted into methanol using a variety of enzymes. Using NADH as a coenzyme, CO2 is reduced to methanol by the successive actions of formate dehydrogenase (FateDH), hydrogenase (FaldDH), and alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH). But the enzyme is inactivated during the reaction, and it consumes a lot of NADH. The high yield and selectivity of CO2 catalyzed by enzymes, the high cost and the difficulty to imitate in vitro limit its industrial application. 3.1.5 CO2 catalyzed by low-temperature plasma Plasma is an ionized gaseous substance composed of positive and negative ions produced by ionizing atoms and atomic groups after partial electron stripping. It can provide a large number of neutral species (molecules, free radicals and excited state species), positive and negative ions, photons and high-energy electrons to participate in the catalytic reaction. It can also reduce the energy barrier of catalytic reactions while breaking the inert chemical bonds under low temperature conditions [73]. Moreover, the combination of plasma and catalyst can achieve the micro and nano scale particle behavior regulation to improve the selectivity of specific products under the condition of plasma, which is a new way of precise activation and surface oriented coupling [74]. In the actual reaction process, the plasma and catalyst will interact with each other, including the plasma can change the physical and chemical properties of the material by generating energetic particles, and the porous structure and dielectric properties of the catalyst will cause local electric field distortion [75]. Overall, the synergistic effect between the integrated plasma and catalyst is shown in improving the energy efficiency, yield and selectivity of the target product of the total reaction, as depicted in Fig. 8 . Low temperature plasma technology can overcome the adverse factors in the thermodynamics of CO2 conversion, and the chemical reactions can be driven at normal temperature and pressure, which mainly revolve around CO2 cracking, CO2 hydrogenation, and CO2/CH4 dry reforming [76–78]. The current difficulty and challenge are how to obtain high CO2 conversion and energy efficiency at the same time. To solve this problem, it is urgent to innovate plasma reactors and design new catalyst systems. The acid-base of the carrier, the type of active center and its coordination structure will all affect the conversion and selectivity of CO2. Catalytic materials with good plasma response activity prepared by simple methods will gradually be favored. 3.2 Development of catalysts The reaction of CO2 on the catalyst belongs to gas-solid multiphase catalytic reaction, which mainly includes three processes: adsorption, reaction and desorption, and at least one reactant participates in the adsorption [79]. First, CO2 molecules are adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. Then it diffuses on the surface, and a series of complex proton and electron transfer processes occur with the catalyst molecules. The resulting reduction products are desorbed from the surface of the catalyst. Hence, the catalyst plays a momentous role in the whole reaction process. In addition, the carrier will affect the electronic structure and chemical environment of the catalyst molecules, and then affect the bonding strength between the catalyst surface and the reaction intermediates. Different bonding strengths will produce different products, so selecting the appropriate carrier will be conducive to improving the selectivity of the catalyst. 3.2.1 Active components Table 2 lists the main active components of CO2 catalytic conversion and the main problems. According to the contact state between the catalyst and reactant, the catalysts for CO2 conversion can be divided into two kinds: homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. In the study of CO2 conversion, the homogeneous catalysts are often used to prepare cyclic carbonates by catalytic coupling of CO2 and epoxides, such as alkali metal salts, quaternary ammonium salts and metal complexes, among which transition metal complexes account for a high proportion [44]. Due to the variable oxidation state and coordination number of transition metal complexes, Ru, Pd, Rh and Ir are widely used in various organic syntheses [84,85]. Transition metal homogeneous catalysis is one of the most promising methods for CO2 conversion from high value-added organic compounds. Although homogeneous catalyst has very high activity, it is difficult to separate and recover. Compared with homogeneous catalysis, heterogeneous CO2 catalytic conversion has the advantages of easy separation and recovery of products, low cost and wide application. In heterogeneous CO2-catalyzed reactions, precious metals such as Au, Ag, Pd, Pt and their alloy catalysts are extensively used due to their advantages of high selectivity, good stability and good reactivity. Especially in the catalytic research of RWGS reactions, Pt and Pd catalysts have received more attention [22]. For the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, formic acid products are the simplest and the reaction mechanism is relatively mature, in which metal catalysts (including Pb, Sn, In, Bi, etc.) with good selectivity to key intermediates *COOH [86]. If CO is generated by electrocatalysis, the catalyst is supposed to be able to selectively generate *COOH, and the adsorption stability of CO is weak, while the catalysts that meet such requirements include metal catalysts such as Au and Ag [87]. However, the high cost and easy aggregation of precious metals limit their large-scale application. The relatively low price, and the content of a wide range of non-precious metals such as Ni, Cu and Fe thus received enhanced attention. Nickel-based catalysts are often used in the reaction of producing methane catalyzed by CO2 [88]. To reduce the energy input of CO2 methanation, researchers are trying to improve the low temperature activity of Ni-based catalysts [89]. At high reaction temperatures and exothermic operation, nickel particles are easy to agglomerate and sinter, resulting in catalyst deactivation. The modification of the Ni-based catalyst can improve the catalytic performance and sintering resistance of the catalyst by regulating the interaction between the Ni particles and the support [90]. Cu-based catalyst is the most typical transition metal catalyst in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol [81]. In the FTS pathway, Fe-based catalysts are considered to be one of the most suitable catalysts for olefin production. Fe carbides are considered to be the active components in the hydrogenation of CO to CHx monomer, and Fe3O4 can effectively catalyze the RWGS reaction [91]. In addition, iron can be used to replace precious metals such as Au, Ag and Pt to achieve the large-scale application of photocatalytic reduction of CO2 [92]. However, the performance of a single-component iron catalyst is far from the requirements of practical application. Currently, the main modification methods include co-catalyst doping modification and catalyst carrier modification to improve the reactivity of catalyst and the selectivity of hydrocarbon products. 3.2.2 Catalyst carrier The selection of suitable carrier materials usually considers the following issues: the carrier configuration, the ability of carriers to regulate electron and structural interactions, the effect of surface alkalinity and acidity on the adsorption and activation of CO2 and H2, and the effect on the promotion of mass transfer on carriers. To combine the advantages of high activity and selectivity of homogeneous catalysts and the advantages of easy separation and recycling of heterogeneous catalysts, the study of heterogeneous metal complexes has been progressively developed. In recent years, some new skeleton materials have many advantages, such as large surface area, clear pore size, convenient use and diversified synthesis routes have attracted vast attention in the fields of gas absorption, separation and catalysis fields, such as covalent organic frameworks (COFs), porous organic polymers (POPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [93,94]. This kind of skeleton material mainly uses organic matter as the linker, which is easy to modify and adjust, and to introduces the coordination site, which provides a new opportunity for the development of new catalytic materials. Among them, MOFs due to their high potential for CO2 adsorption, high porosity, robust structures, and maximum atom utilization have been given a lot of attention [95,96]. The strong interaction of metal carrier plays an imperative role in the catalytic process of multiphase catalyst systems. The carrier can not only prevent the aggregation of the catalyst in the catalytic process, but also has the effect of chemical coupling with the catalyst, which can change the surface electronic structure of the catalyst, affect the electron transfer pathway, enhance the catalytic activity of the catalyst, and improve the catalytic selectivity. At present, the widely studied carriers are SiO2, Al2O3, molecular sieve, TiO2 and so on [90,97–99]. In addition, the combination of carbon materials (such as graphene oxides, carbon nanotubes, biochar, hydrothermal carbon, and activated carbon) with donor and acceptor properties and the catalyst to synthesize composite materials also has the effect of improving the activity of the catalyst [100]. 3.2.3 Heteroatom doping Heteroatom doping can modify the surface electronic structure of the catalyst, or the doped atoms have a significant selectivity for a key intermediate, to improve the catalytic activity of the catalytic reduction of CO2. There are two kinds of doping modes: nonmetal atom doping and metal atom doping. In terms of nonmetallic atom doping, N, P, S and other nonmetallic atoms have been successfully doped in graphene, carbon nanotubes and other carbon nanomaterials [101–104]. This structure can induce defect formation because the electronegativity difference between the carbon and doping atoms destroys the original network structure. The addition of K to Cr-based catalysts significantly improved the catalytic stability and ethylene selectivity of the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane with CO2 [105]. Experimental and theoretical calculations show that the catalyst doped with metal atoms can lower the formation barrier of reaction intermediates because of its specific electronic structure and low coordination [106]. Metal atom doping is mainly used for the preparation of heterogeneous monatomic catalysts, and the carbon is used as the carrier. This structure reduces the formation barrier of reaction intermediates, promotes electron transfer, and improves the catalytic activity of catalytic reduction of CO2 through the coordination of isolated distributed metal and carbon atoms [107,108]. Defects can provide more active sites and change the electron transfer pathway, further improving the catalytic activity. When another metal is added to a metal catalyst to form an alloy or bimetallic interface, a certain lattice stress will be generated due to the inconsistency of the crystallographic constants of the two catalysts. This stress will further affect the geometric and electronic structure of the catalyst, and lead to the change in the atomic distance on the surface and the movement of the metal electron center, so the activity and selectivity of the catalyst will correspondingly change [109]. For example, in the process of CO2 reduction synthesis of methanol catalyzed by Pd, ZnO [110], CeO2 [111], CuO [112] and In2O3 [113] were added to aid Pd particles disperse, and stabilize or form bimetallic compounds. Meanwhile, the alkaline sites on the surface of metal oxide additives and the oxygen vacancies formed by reduction are conducive to the adsorption and activation of CO2. 3.2.4 Other effects In addition to the types of active components, carriers and heteroatom doping effects, synergistic effects and size effects also affect the catalytic conversion of carbon dioxide. Tandem catalysis not only can pull the reaction through the effective coupling between the active components, but also can save the purification and separation process of the intermediate products, and reduce the energy consumption of the reaction. Jiao et al. [114] proposed the concept of "tandem catalysis" for the first time in the field of syngas conversion, breaking through the limitation that the selectivity of the final product in FTS follows a certain steady-state distribution, namely, "Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution" [115]. The "tandem catalysis" process combines the traditional FTS catalyst with the molecular sieve phase, so that there are two or more catalytic active sites in the reaction system. The synthesis gas was desorbed on the traditional FTS catalyst to generate primary low carbon products. The desorbed product molecules entered into the pore of the sieve and were catalyzed by the Brønsted acid site to further transform a variety of hydrocarbon products [98]. The synergistic effect between the active components and the carrier (such as the uniformly distributed MoO2 nanoparticles and porous carbon structure) can affect the physicochemical parameters (such as specific surface area and active site) [116,117], thereby affecting the CO2 conversion rate and the selectivity of the target products. The doping-inducted heterojunction is also an effective strategy to boost electrocatalysis and photocatalysis [118]. Compared with materials with a single structure, the construction of heterojunctions can achieve synergistic interactions between different components, while electron transfer between the heterojunction interfaces can optimize the electronic structure [119]. Researchers often compound active substances with carbon materials to construct heterojunction structures, such as graphitized carbon nitride (g-C3N4) [68,120,121]. Nano-structured catalysts with different sizes have unalike catalytic activity and product selectivity, which is called the catalytic size effect. The smaller the size of the catalyst, the larger the specific surface area, the lower the average coordination number of surface atoms, and the more unsaturated sites. These unsaturated sites often become the active sites of the reaction by changing the electronic structure of the atom itself to improve the activity of the reaction [33,96,113]. 4 Demonstration projects of CO2 conversion in China 4.1 Development stage of CO2 conversion technology Global CCUS projects are growing rapidly, with the number of commercial CCUS facilities planned, under construction or in operation more than doubling from 2020 to 135 by September 2021, with the capacity to capture approximately 150 million tons of CO2 per year when fully completed [122]. Zhang et al. [123] summarized the developmental stage of CO2 conversion technology, as shown in Fig. 9 . The analysis shows that, compared with the CCUS technology of capture, transportation, geological use and storage, integrated optimization, CO2 transformation technology in China develops relatively slowly. Although it has a few industrial demonstration projects, it lacks the commercial application of industrial scale (more than 5 industrial scales are or completed in operation). The research on the technology of CO2 methanol production has made great ameliorate in recent years in China. Li Can's groups from Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences have developed Liquid sunshine methanol technology [124]. Through the use of renewable energy such as solar energy, wind energy and water energy to generate electricity, combined with electrolytic water hydrogen production (green hydrogen) and CO2 hydrogenation technology to produce methanol, the renewable energy is stored and utilized in the form of liquid fuel methanol. In 2020, the world's first kiloton solar fuel synthesis demonstration project has been successfully tested, and the energy conversion efficiency from solar energy to liquid fuel methanol is greater than 14%. A 100,000 TPA “Liquid Sunshine” demonstration project is currently being prepared. In 2020, the world's first set of 5000 tons/year CO2 hydrogenation to methanol industrial test equipment has also achieved stable operation from the development of China Chengda Engineering CO. LTD. and Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Science. For the application of DRM, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Science, Lu'an Chemical Group CO. LTD. and Shell Group of Companies jointly researched the key technologies of DRM synthesis gas [125]. It has achieved the world's first DRM 10,000 m3 device, which has been operated stably, and the conversion and utilization of CO2 have reached 60 tons/day, completing the industrial demonstration. The direct synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO2 and methanol is an environmentally friendly green chemical process that has been widely concerned in recent years, but it is still in the research and development stage [126]. Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, together with related companies, realized the systematic innovation of ionic liquid catalyst-reactor-process. In Daya Bay National Petrochemical Zone in Huizhou, Guangdong Province, a 100,000-ton industrial plant for CO2 synthesis of carbonate catalyzed by ionic liquid has been built and it has achieved continuous and stable operation since 2021. Its carbonate (including vinyl carbonate, DMC, etc.) products meet the electronic grade standards, reducing energy consumption by 37% and achieving a significant carbon reduction effect. In the direct synthesis of polycarbonates from CO2, Mongolia Mengxi Group and China National Offshore Oil Corporation both have used the technology from the Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Science [127] to build two 3000 t/a aliphatic polycarbonate industrial demonstration devices, respectively. The direct synthesis of low carbon olefin, liquefied petroleum gas, aromatics and jet fuel distillates by CO2 hydrogenation can be achieved by using a dual-function catalyst system and coupling various reaction mechanisms. In 2017, Sun Yuhan group from Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Science firstly achieved the direct hydrogenation of CO2 to synthesize gasoline fractions containing high isomerized hydrocarbon (C5-C11) and established a new reaction platform for the direct synthesis of high value C2+ hydrocarbons by CO2 hydrogenation [128]. In 2022, this group successfully realized relay, function matching and optimization of RWGS reaction and FTS reaction, and realized direct conversion of CO2 hydrogenation into olefin and alcohol under relatively mild conditions [129]. In the same year, Zeng Jie's group at the University of Science and Technology of China achieved a high selectivity of long chain olefin by hydrogenation of CO2 at atmospheric pressure. The selectivity of long chain olefin reached 66.9%, which was similar to the result under high pressure (66.8%) [7]. The groundbreaking ceremony was held for the world's first 10,000-ton CO2 hydrogenation to aromatics industrial test project jointly built by Tsinghua University and Jiutai Group, further promoting the industrial route of CO2 production of high-end chemicals. Moreover, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences and Belinda Zhuhai Energy Technology Co., Ltd. successfully launched the world's first 1000 tons/year CO2 hydrogenation gasoline pilot plant has been successfully put into operation, and produce clean gasoline products in line with VI standards 4.2 Hydrogen and electricity supply Hydrogenation of CO2 is an integral means to recycle CO2, and there are many sources of raw hydrogen. The World Energy Council classifies hydrogen into three categories: “gray hydrogen” prepared by fossil energy, “blue hydrogen” prepared by fossil raw materials and using CCUS, and “green hydrogen” prepared by renewable energy. At present, due to the abundant coal resources in China, considering the cost investment factor, coal hydrogen production technology is the most popularly used. However, the carbon emission in the process of coal hydrogen production is between 19 and 24 kg CO2eq/kg H2 [130], and the carbon emission reduction of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is 7.3 kg CO2eq/kg H2 at most, so the process does not achieve carbon reduction. In addition, the carbon emissions for hydrogen production from natural gas and hydrogen production from electricity (from China Grid, whose emission factor is 0.581 kg CO2eq/kW·h in 2021) are 8.7–10.4 kg CO2eq/kg and 2.6–2.9 kg CO2eq/kg H2, respectively. The process energy consumption, hydrogen consumption and CO2 consumption are 0.52 kW·h/ kg methanol,1.65 kg H2/ kg methanol and 10.6 kg CO2/ kg methanol, respectively [131,132]. Based on these data, the carbon emission reduction of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol process can be calculated under different carbon emission factors of hydrogen and electricity. As indicated in Fig. 10 , the carbon emission from the hydrogen production process is the main carbon emission source in the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. In addition, only when the carbon emission factor of hydrogen is lower than 6 kg CO2eq/kg H2, the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol may begin to have carbon emission reduction characteristics. Therefore, only “green hydrogen” and “green electricity” can truly achieve zero carbon emissions. Obtaining cheap and zero-carbon hydrogen is the requirement to determine the economy of CO2 hydro-conversion technology. In the short term, CO2 hydrogenation technology can be combined with hydrogen-rich industries (propane dehydrogenation, ethane cracking, coke oven gas and chlor-alkali, etc.) to achieve low cost, green and high value-added chemical synthesis, and drive the transformation and upgrading of traditional industries. In the medium and long term, with the progress of electrolysis hydrogen production technology and the reduction of cost, it can combine with “green hydrogen” to achieve the synthesis of carbon negative chemicals, and form a truly circular and sustainable green clean energy ecology. 5 Conclusions and recommendations 5.1 Conclusions With people's concern about green chemistry and carbon neutral development mode, CO2 catalytic conversion to chemicals has received numerous attentions. In this paper, the CO2 chemical reaction network and the process of CO2 catalytic conversion (including catalytic system and catalyst) as well as their advantages and disadvantages are reviewed, and the current technological developmental stage of CO2 catalytic conversion to chemicals and the influence of hydrogen and electricity supply are discussed. The main conclusions are as follows: At present, CO2 products mainly include organic fuels (such as methanol, dimethyl ether, etc.), syngas, polymer materials (such as polycarbonate, degradable polymer materials, etc.), bulk chemicals (such as urea, salicylic acid, etc.). On the whole, CO2 conversion products should have the advantages of a simple process, less energy and raw material consumption, friendly environment, high added value, single product and high yield. However, different conversion paths have their shortcomings, such as high energy consumption in the process of making organic fuel and syngas, poor selectivity in the process of making polymer materials and low yield. In terms of CO2 catalytic conversion system, the more mature one is thermal catalysis though it requires harsh conditions of high temperature and high pressure. Photocatalysis is the most environmentally friendly and also the least efficient. The energy efficiency of electrocatalysis is high, but the product selectivity is not significant. The yield and CO2 conversion rate of enzyme catalysis are higher, but the microenvironment requirements and the cost of coenzyme are more prominent. Plasma catalysis can achieve a high conversion rate, but the energy efficiency is low. In addition, most of the current research is in the laboratory stage, so how to further improve the reaction efficiency to adapt to large-scale applications is the key problem of future research. Although the catalytic conversion method is different, its development is limited by the catalyst. Catalyst plays a pivotal role in the conversion and utilization of CO2 and is a mandatory way to improve efficiency. The noble metal catalysts in different CO2 catalytic conversion methods all show good catalytic performance, but due to their high price, loading and other methods are usually chosen to reduce the noble metal content while maintaining the catalytic performance as far as possible. In addition, it is still necessary to overcome the shortcomings of high temperature sintering, and carbon deposition resulting in catalyst inactivation and low selectivity. For non-noble metal catalysts, it can be considered doping metal elements to change the acid base of the catalyst or change the preparation method, and introduce an ultrasonic energy field in the preparation process to regulate the pore structure of the catalyst and the particle size of the active component. In terms of industrial demonstration, the industrial demonstration of DRM and CO2 synthesis cyclocarbonate has been promoted relatively quickly, but there is still no industrial commercial application. With the emergence of “liquid sunlight” technology, the popular of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol has surged in recent years. Its main advantages are as follows: (1) high value-added chemicals can be obtained at the same time as the resource utilization of CO2; (2) renewable energy such as wind energy and photovoltaic energy can be converted into electricity and then stored in methanol, making energy easy to store and transport, and improving the utilization rate of chemical energy; (3) methanol is an important intermediate product of chemical raw materials, through which a vast system of chemical products can be synthesized. Due to the low maturity of CO2 liquid fuel technology, there is a lack of relevant industrial demonstration. In addition to the maturity of CO2 catalytic conversion technology, relevant supporting integrated units will also have a great impact on the engineering application of CO2 catalytic conversion technology. If the carbon emission factor of the supplied hydrogen is higher than 6 kg CO2eq/kg H2, the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol must not have carbon emission reduction characteristics. 5.2 Recommendations The active development of CO2 catalytic conversion technology is helpful to alleviate CO2 emission and contribute to the sustainable development of chemical industry. To achieve high quality and scale development of CO2 resource utilization technology, three suggestions are proposed as follows: (1) Enriching CO2 conversion products and selecting the best reaction path. As an important carbon source in the future, CO2 conversion has a rich product chain, and there is still an opportunity to achieve further expansion in the future. In this regard, it is suggested that on the premise of studying the further development of market demand and CO2 conversion technology (including expanding the CO2 conversion reaction network and improving the existing reaction ways), the relationship between technology, demand and development potential should be fully considered, and the best reaction path should be selected to promote the diversified development of CO2 products and avoid the problem of homogenization and excess production capacity. (2) Designing catalysts with high efficiency and high selectivity, and exploring the relevant catalytic mechanism. As CO2 is an inert reactant, the activation process is the premise of its conversion reaction. Therefore, the efficient and highly selective catalytic system has become the key to the chemical utilization process of CO2. However, current technologies such as thermal catalysis, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, enzyme catalysis and plasma catalysis are still in the exploring and developing stage, and an efficient catalytic system has not been formed. The fundamental reason is that CO2 activation, reaction mechanism and catalytic action mechanism are not clear, so it is impossible to carry out the innovative design of catalysts and achieve precise regulation of products. (3) Reducing the use-cost of green hydrogen and green electricity, and strengthening the deployment of demonstration projects. As raw material supply units and energy supply units, green hydrogen and green electricity as emerging industries face the problems of high energy consumption, high cost and few engineering practices, which will also have a direct impact on the engineering application of CO2 catalytic conversion technology. In this regard, it is suggested to vigorously support the deployment of demonstration projects of new CO2 catalytic conversion technologies, and coordinate the integrated optimization of CO2 utilization methods in the industry dimension, so as to reduce emission reduction costs and promote the large-scale development of CO2 resource utilization. coredata.dc:description: To achieve the global net-zero carbon emissions target, enhanced studies on how to effectively convert and utilize CO2 have been conducted. Herein, the research progress and development trend of CO2 conversion to chemicals, including CO2 hydrogenation to hydrocarbons, CO2 as an oxidant to syngas, and CO2 cycloaddition to carbonate were discussed in this review. The principles, advantages, disadvantages, and prospects of thermal catalysis, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, enzyme catalysis, and plasma catalysis for CO2 conversion were summarized. Among them, the different methods of the active component, carrier, catalyst electronic effect, synergistic effect and size effect used to develop specific catalysts for different CO2 conversions were introduced emphatically. Moreover, the developmental stage of CO2 catalytic conversion technology and important industrial demonstration projects in China were summarized, with special emphasis on the relationship between hydrogen/electricity supply and the carbon emission reduction effect of CO2 catalytic conversion. The reaction network, catalytic system and demonstration project of CO2 catalytic conversion were comprehensively compared and discussed to more clearly play the beneficial role of CO2 catalytic conversion in carbon reduction work.
coredata.dc:title: Recent advances in the catalytic conversion of CO2 to chemicals and demonstration projects in China
